Steve LaFleur, leader of the influential Cajun rock band Mamou, passed away on August 9, 2020. In this clip from 1990, Steve tells about Ugly Day, an outdoor music party that sparked the idea for creation of the band Mamou. Following that is one of Steve's original songs: "Homme A Pitier." A mixture of Cajun music and rock and roll, Mamou had the ability to please and surprise fans of both types of music, sometimes with a traditional version of "Jolie Blonde" or sometimes with a wild version of "La Danse De Mardi Gras" featuring twin fiddles through "wah-wah" pedals plugged into Marshall amplifiers stacked high.

The Mamou / Jungle Records Collection, donated to the Center for Louisiana Studies in 2019, features live and commercial recordings, promotional materials, photographs, and videos of Mamou.

Know of a legend or tradition in your community that deserves to be honored with a permanent marker? Center for Louisiana Studies partnering organization the William G. Pomeroy Foundation opens a new round of Legends and Lore marker applications today (August 17)!

Examples of the type of things that could be nominated for celebration are:
-Legends, or semi-historical tales, that are told as true, but not verifiable, such as the many stories of the pirate Jean Lafitte's treasure
-Myths, or sacred explanatory stories, involving Louisiana geography, such as those involving locations venerated in Native American traditions
-Places or people mentioned in famed traditional songs or stories, such as "Opelousas Sosthène"
-The birthplace or burial ground of significant carriers of Louisiana folklore, such as Dennis McGee or Clifton Chenier
-Placenames with with intriguing and indeterminate folk etymologies, such as "Carencro"

post_text: Yesterday was the birthday of accordion building legend Randy Falcon (August 11, 1950), who unfortunately passed away on May 23, 2020. Originally from Duson, Louisiana, Falcon was a master diatonic or button accordion builder who has honed his craft over four decades. He learned to make instruments by apprenticing with legendary accordion maker Shine Mouton and then, in turn, he trained several others. Not only did Falcon become one of the preeminent builders of this traditional instrument, he also made advances in the field- building the first accordion that could play in two different keys. He received the Louisiana Folklife Tradition Bearer Award in 2017 and established a collection of his audio and video materials at the Center for Louisiana Studies the same year. Rest in Peace Randy.

We are thrilled to announce that Michael Tisserand, author of "The Kingdom of Zydeco," has donated his fieldwork collection to the Center for Louisiana Studies. We have digitized 12 out of nearly 200 tapes and are excited to start making these recordings available to researchers as soon as possible. Here are a few words from Michael and also a clip from his interview with the great Creole fiddler, Bébé Carrière.

"I owe everything in The Kingdom of Zydeco and my other Creole, Cajun and zydeco research and writing to the musicians, families, dancers and scholars who helped me understand the depth of culture and history — and especially the depth of soul — that is zydeco. It's my hope that by donating these interview tapes and other materials to the Center for Louisiana Studies's Archive of Cajun and Creole Folklore at University of Louisiana at Lafayette, it will further connect present and future students of this exciting music to the lives and art of zydeco's visionary, hard-working, and ever-creative pioneers."

Sidney Brown (October 28, 1906-August 6, 1981)

Sidney Brown, originally from Church Point, was not only a well known musician, but also the first person in Louisiana to build a Cajun accordion. His recording of "Pestauche Ah Tante Nana" with his band The Traveler Playboys was a hit for the Lake Charles label, Goldband Records, in 1953. Here in a video from the Randy Falcon Collection shot in 1979, he discusses how he got interested in building accordions with Pat Savant and then gives an example of his playing, accompanied by Randy Falcon on guitar.

Congratulations to the 2020 winners of the Neitzel Family Endowed Student Awards in Louisiana Studies, Rex Jones and Regina Lowe. The Neitzel Award recognizes outstanding student scholarship at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette in any field related to Louisiana Studies, including but not limited to history, folklore, languages, music, geography, anthropology, archaeology, literature, architecture, and the visual arts.

Rex Jones, Graduate student in the History Department, won with the submission of his Master’s thesis, “Two Quiet Revolutions and the Transformation of American Healthcare.”

Regina Lowe, undergraduate student working on a double major in the Anthropology and History Departments, won with her paper, “Mounds and the Landscape of the Middle Archaic Period,” which was submitted as class work from the Spring 2020 Anthropology course, Southeastern Archaeology.

Please join the Center for Louisiana Studies, the Neitzel Family, and the Award Selection Committee in extending congratulations to Rex and Regina!

The Center for Louisiana Studies is looking for native speakers of Louisiana French who would like to be interviewed in French about how their lives have changed since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. The objective of the Cajun and Creole COVID Collection (CCCC) is to collect and archive audiovisual materials related to the coronavirus in southern Louisiana and its impact on and manifestations in Cajun and Creole culture and language. The interviews will be stored at the Archives of Cajun and Creole Folklore at UL-Lafayette.

MAY 29, 2020 - Lafayette, Louisiana:

The Center for Louisiana Studies has announced the appointment of its new class of fellows. Appointed for five year terms, fellows of the Center for Louisiana Studies are recognized voices in Louisiana Studies who work in close affiliation with the Center during their tenure, advising and guiding the strategy and continued evolution of the Center and its mission.

"We are extremely excited and honored to welcome this new group of Fellows," said Center for Louisiana Studies Director, Dr. Joshua Caffery. "These are individuals whose work has already had an impact on the Center, on the communities they work in, and on the broader fields of Louisiana Studies. They are multi-faceted scholars who combine intellectual rigor with creativity, passion, and a consideration of the public interest, and I'm thrilled that they will be working more closely with the Center in the coming years."

To learn more about the Fellows of the Center for Louisiana Studies, click below:

It's hard to separate Louisiana history from the history of epidemic disease. There's even a good argument to be made that the first recorded zydeco song deals largely with this very subject:

Recorded by John and Alan Lomax in New Iberia June 1934, Wilfred Charles is the first singer we know of to use the phrase, "Les haricots sont pas salés" (where most people believe the word zydeco comes from) on record.

The lyrics of the song mostly deal with the plight of sick Italian-Americans (here, "dagos"), who were the most conspicuous victims of the yellow fever epidemics of the 18th and early 19th century, especially in New Orleans and in the sugar parishes of the lower Bayou Teche, where they worked alongside African Americans:
https://www.lomax1934.com/deacutegozydeco.html

After he hatches from an egg, Jeremy learns to walk, eat grass, swim, cross the road, and get along with other animals, all under the watchful eyes of his Mom and Dad. On the banks of the park’s lagoon, Jeremy and his family live with their neighbors, including a squirrel, a snake, and a bad-mannered nutria. Jeremy is a thoughtful and sensitive little goose who sometimes gets into trouble but always feels the love of his family. Through Jeremy’s voice, young readers learn about family, responsibility, having fun, and growing up.

The Center for Louisiana Studies is sad to report that Larry Benicewicz, a champion of traditional South Louisiana music, passed away last week in Baltimore, Maryland. Benicewicz interviewed and wrote about many zydeco and swamp pop musicians, assisted in promoting
their tours in the Northeastern US, and was proclaimed an honorary state citizen in 1993 by Gov. Edwin Edwards for his promotion of Louisiana music. His love of Louisiana music culture is evident in this small group of images from his collection (currently being processed), including 1) Roy Carrier and Benicewicz in 2005, 2) Beau Jocque at Richard's Club, 1990s, 3) Fernest Arceneaux, 1990s, 4) Lee Lavergne of Lanor Records and Preston Frank, 1992, 5) Goldband Records, Lake Charles, 1993, and 6) Clifton Chenier at one of his last performances, New York City, 1987.

post_text: Sad to hear that music legend Paul "Lil' Buck" Sinegal passed away today. A true musician, Buck fronted his own band, recorded blues sessions at Excello Records, recorded his own funky tunes for La Louisiane Records, was a sideman for numerous legendary acts such as Lee Dorsey, Carol Fran, and Joe Tex, played in Clifton Chenier's Red Hot Louisiana Band, Lil' Band O' Gold, and Rockin' Dopsie. Louisiana music fans have grown accustomed to hearing Sinegal's guitar playing on records and the radio, and live in many settings- from small weekly blues jams to large festival stages. To say that his death leaves a huge hole is no exaggeration. Here he is playing with Rockin' Dopise and the Twisters in 1988. Rest in Peace Lil' Buck.

Happy birthday to Cajun fiddle legend and South Louisiana Ambassador Dewey Balfa (March 20, 1927- June 17, 1992)!
Faced with the daunting task of starting a local repository of cultural heritage materials in the early Seventies, Dr. Barry Ancelet asked Balfa how he thought he might proceed. His reply was "Record one tape and put it on a shelf, then do it again!" Because of that advice, the Archives of Cajun and Creole Folklore at the Center for Louisiana Studies exists! Thank you Mr. Dewey!
Here is a 1991 clip of Balfa accompanied on guitar by his friend and songwriting legend Shirley Ray Bergeron.

Hey all you Harry Trahan music fans! Renee and I are in the process of gathering, documenting and preserving dad’s music at the Center for Louisiana Studies at UL. Renee is actually working there and documenting her own family’s music! She couldn’t be happier!❤️
I am reaching out to all of you because I know there are some recordings out there we have not heard. We are interested in all recordings and videos of dad.
Also, in particular, we believe there are some dancehall recordings made by Huey Meaux in Texas. Dad played there from 1956-1962. He played dancehalls 4 nights a week. If anyone has access to this, and could share it, it would be priceless to our family and it could be preserved for everyone studying our heritage. I’m crossing my fingers...
Please feel free to share this with anyone who might have information. Thanks!!!
